did.abstract: Hymen Schlesinger was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, in 1903 and began practicing law in 1927. His specialty was maritime law, but his political orientations led him to argue cases on behalf of labor unions, minorities, and accused Communists. The collection contains legal papers, correspondence, and news clippings particularly related to the above kinds of cases. Materials relating to the sedition trial of communist party district leader Steve Nelson are also present.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Hymen Schlesinger was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, in 1903. He attended Princeton University and he attended Duquesne University's School of Law for one year, but earned his professional status as an attorney through an apprenticeship. (per information provided by his daughter) His specialty was maritime law, but his political orientations led him to argue cases on behalf of labor unions, minorities, and accused Communists. He was crucially involved in defending the foreign-born against deportation proceedings filed under the Walter-McCarran Act of 1952; and he successfully appealed disbarment proceedings that were brought against him by a local lawyers' committee accusing him of communist affiliation. Schlesinger passed away in Pittsburgh on February 5, 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection contains legal papers, correspondence, and news clippings related to the career of Hymen Schlesinger. Cases involving deportation, denaturalization, civil rights of African Americans and alleged Communist party membership, as well as Schlesinger's own disbarment case and materials related to the trials of Communist district leader Steve Nelson, are particularly noteworthy. Also included are various publications pertaining to Communism and legal issues in Pennsylvania. In cases involving accused Communists, Schlesinger's main defense strategy was to attempt to discredit the testimony of government informers. Background files on informers, including Matthew Cvetic and Joseph Mazzei, are examples of this strategy. Another feature of the collection are related materials developed by University of Pittsburgh Labor Archivist David Rosenberg (retired). Overall, the Schlesinger Papers are one of the richest and most concentrated set of research materials available anywhere on the Red Scare in Pittsburgh.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains materials protected by attorney-client privilege and, therefore, may be subject to review prior to researcher use. Access to privileged documents will be restricted in compliance with attorney-client confidentiality. This restriction in particular pertains to the two Barr-Walker cases, which have been moved to a box at the end of the collection. Please contact the Archives Service Center for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information regarding several of the labor unions that Schlesinger represented throughout his career. Present are legal papers, correspondence, and news clippings detailing several cases involving union locals, workers, and communism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and other documents concerning Schlesinger's representation of UE Local 610 before the War Labor Board about wage rate issues and also for some insurance matters. Legal papers on arbitration between General Electric and UE are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and memos from David Scribner of the UE Legal Department and materials regarding the Hartley Committee investigation of the UE in Evansville, Iowa, are present. There is also a letter from Thomas Quinn to Schlesinger which terminated the lawyer's professional relationship with the UE.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Included are correspondence, legal papers, constitutions, and by-laws relating to the UE v. Williamsport Battery Co. case. A handwritten letter by Schlesinger to AT&T on behalf of women telephone workers is also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files contain correspondence between this local of the Shipbuilders' Union and the Dravo Corporation, as well as legal briefs that were presented before the War Labor Board.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files include correspondence regarding the discharge of two deckhands and copies of proposed legislation affecting maritime affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Legal papers and correspondence concerning Schlesinger's work on behalf of union workers at the Pennsylvania Railroad works in Altoona who claimed illegal trusteeship was placed on their local and that they were denied their right to stand for election. Pamphlets from the Department of Labor explaining aspects of the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: In 1950, charges were filed claiming that Schlesinger was a member of the Communist party and calling for his disbarment. Hearings for the case began in 1954 and the struggle lasted for about ten years. This series consists of correspondence outlining Schlesinger's efforts to find representation, as well as of proceedings during the case. Legal papers filed by Schlesinger and the prosecution, the Committee on Offenses of the Courts of Common Pleas in Allegheny County, are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains newspaper clippings, leaflets, and legal papers documenting the contribution of undercover informers Joseph Mazzei and Matt Cvetic, who testified against hundreds of alleged communists at the House Un-American Activities Committee hearings during February and March of 1950. Phonodisc, reel to reel, and transcript copies of a speech by Cvetic at East Pittsburgh High School in March 19, 1950 are included. In the speech, Cvetic urged the Westinghouse union members to join the IUE instead of the UE which he denounced as a communist organization. Memos by Schlesinger regarding anti-Communist Judge Michael Musmanno are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The files in this series contain information related to individual cases and people Schlesinger represented. Many of the documents are legal papers from the trials, but correspondence and clippings are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains files related to Schlesinger's politically charged cases. These particular cases dealt with alleged Communists and civil rights issues. Within the files are legal papers and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This case involved a school teacher who was fired after Cvetic accused her of being a Communist. The file includes legal papers and minutes from the Board of Education discussing her case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Schlesinger defended Nathan Albert who was arrested under charges of attempting to incite a riot while trying to integrate Highland Park swimming pool in Pittsburgh. In a prior case, Albert appealed for compensation after he sued his employer, F.J. Kress Box Co., for wrongful dismissal. He was also alleged to be a member of the Communist party. Legal papers, correspondence, and clippings regarding the cases are present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This case was concerned with an African American defendant's issues regarding the setting of bail.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This case involves Benjamin Davis, an African American defendant who opposed various forms of segregation and racism within Allegheny County Jail. Davis served as a New York City councilman from 1943 to 1949 until he was convicted under the Smith Act for being a Communist. Legal papers, correspondence, and clippings regarding his case are present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Schlesinger represented these alleged Communist party members who were to be denaturalized and deported under the Walter-McCarran Act. Included are legal papers and a leaflet from the Committee to Defend Anna and Steve Devunich.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file includes correspondence regarding Dudash's alleged Communist membership and the dismissal of her case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Hashmall was brought to court under the Smith Act, which made it illegal to advocate or teach others to advocate the overthrow of the United States government by force. This file contains legal papers and correspondence relating to Hashmall's case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Schlesinger defended the Kemenovichs, alleged Communist party members, in this case in which the Croatian-born Kemenovichs were ordered to be deported under the Walter-McCarran Act. Included are legal papers and a leaflet from the Western Pennsylvania Committee for the Protection of Foreign Born.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: McNeil was a union organizer for the United Electrical, Radio, and Machine Workers of America and a purported Communist party member. These files include legal papers and correspondence documenting his deportation case. There are also documents regarding the Committee to End Sedition Laws and regarding the House Un-American Activities Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file contains legal papers regarding Mankin's denaturalization and deportation case. He was a Lithuanian-born Jewish union organizer and alleged Communist who lived on the North Side of Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Schlesinger represented Miller, an alleged member of the Communist party, in this deportation case. Documents include legal papers relating to the case in which the Yugoslavian born Miller was accused of lying on his naturalization papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This case involves an African American defendant who escaped from a Georgia prison camp. A judge in Pennsylvania refused to extradite Moreland to Georgia due to rumors of cruelty to African American prisoners. This file includes legal papers and clippings regarding this case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file contains legal papers relating to Nuss' case in which she was removed from public assistance because she was an alleged member of the Communist party.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files contain legal papers regarding Patrick being convicted of crimes. There are also documents relating to Patrick being beaten by guards while in prison and accusations of racism within the jail.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files include legal papers and news clippings regarding a public interest suit that attempted to block the increase of trolley rates. The papers mostly deal with the legality of the company raising fares without federal judge approval, but some clippings are concerned with the possible Communist party affiliation of some of those who took action against the company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Schlesinger represented this United Mine Worker and alleged Communist party member in his deportation case under the Walter-McCarran Act. The file contains legal papers and correspondence regarding the case, as well as a Polish hearing transcript.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Salis was accused of being a member of the Communist party after being arrested for distributing flyers at the gates of the National Tube Works in McKeesport, Pa. Included in the file are legal papers and news clippings in which Schlesinger and Salis claim that his arrest was a violation of his First Amendment rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This case includes legal papers, news clippings, and hearing transcripts relating to this deportation case in which Santes was accused of being a member of the Communist party. Also included is a leaflet from the Western Pennsylvania Committee for the Protection of Foreign Born regarding Santes' possible deportation under the Walter-McCarran Act.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file includes a transcript of Schultz's testimony before the House Un-American Activities Committee. She was the secretary of the Pittsburgh Civil Rights Congress and was accused of being a Communist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files contain legal papers regarding Seder's deportation case in which he was accused of being a Communist. Legal papers regarding Seder's estate are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files contain legal papers, transcripts, and clippings regarding this case in which Soldo, an accused Communist party member, was to be deported. In these files, Schlesinger attempts to discredit Matthew Cvetic, the informer who named Soldo as a Communist. Papers regarding Soldo's divorce proceedings are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Spehar, a Yugoslavian non-citizen steel worker and coal miner living in West Virginia, was accused of being a Communist in this deportation case. Included are correspondence and legal papers relating to the case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file includes a letter from Welch who was referred to Schlesinger by Spicer. In this correspondence he asks for representation in a case against the United States Marine Corp for improper dismissal when he threatened to publicize his report regarding helicopter malfunctions in Vietnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file includes legal papers regarding this case in which a father accused the War Department of racial discrimination during recruitment because his son was denied enlistment because he was an African American. Clippings in this file are concerned with a threat to stop all enlistment until the army desegregated and made recruitment standards equal for all men.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Included in this file are legal papers and news clippings regarding an anti-war protest at South Hills High School started by female members of Students for a Democratic Society, of whom twenty six were arrested.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file includes legal papers and correspondence regarding Terzich's deportation case in which he was accused of being a Communist party member by MattherCvetic and Mary Mazzei. Also present are his petition for naturalization after the deportation case ended and documents on his estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file contains legal papers from Tolsti's deportation case in which he was purported to have been a Communist. A transcript of the hearing is also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This case involved an African American defendant who challenged issues regarding consecutive and concurrent sentences and asserted his right to a fair trial. This file contains legal papers and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files contain newspaper clippings and preliminary census records from 1950 used as exhibits in the United States v. Mesarosh case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file includes correspondence to U.S. Jury Commissioner in the Western District of Pennsylvania William L. Potts which lists the names of several people he deems fit to be added to a Federal jury wheel. Potts sent letters to various companies in the Pittsburgh area requesting the names of qualified employees. A sample of such a letter is present in the file. The defendants later argued that this procedure demonstrated biases in the jury selection process.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file includes an affidavit of Steve Nelson regarding his sedition trial and issues of Political Affairs. Also included is the army discharge certificate of Irving Weissman, a co-defendant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file includes publications on Marxist philosophy and World War II, as well as newspaper clippings from The Worker and a Communist party membership application.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This file contains correspondence regarding Mrs. Nelson's injuries due to a car accident.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files contain correspondence and legal papers relating to a variety of court cases. Examples of estate, personal injury, and child support cases are present. Inmate appeals while in jail challenging court procedure are also included in these documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information on the various types of cases Schlesinger participated in. Many of the denaturalization files contain legal papers regarding the cases of Steve Nelson/Mesarosh and Julia Misloy. Denaturalization and deportation files include a variety of papers, correspondence, and pamphlets regarding the Committee to Protect Foreign Born and people who were involved in denaturalization cases. Files regarding estate, jail, prison, and workhouse cases contain correspondence regarding specific cases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The card file bibliography was compiled by Schlesinger as a way of cataloging newspaper articles in which he, his cases, and other persons, organizations, and events of interest were mentioned. Examples include Matthew Cvetic, Joseph Mazzei, Steve Nelson, Michael J. Musmanno, and Benjamin Davis.
